They honestly look really good in PvE overall. Fast paced and fun with their usual utility. It may take some getting used to building talent loadouts for specific dungeons / content however since it’s difficult to get everything we currently have all of the time.

The class tree is a quite point starved for PvP however. Thunderstorm / Lightning Lasso, Ancestral Guidance, double shields, and things like Earth Shield / Feral Lunge / Wind Rush / Earthgrab / Nature’s Guardian no longer being exclusive are quite nice though healing is still your only real defensive; nothing new to answer stuns and their damage potential is possibly the only thing that might allow branching out of the Tubro comp, but it’s hard to say for sure.
Ascendance is now awesome.

I am absolutely loving my enh shaman with a heavy focused Windfury build! It’s been a blast! The rotation feels good for my personal play style, for my gear and absolute lack of gems, enchants, buff food or pots and flasks in the low keystone I did today I was doing pretty good damage. I can’t imagine how great it’s going to feel with good gear, full enchants and gems, etc.
I really did not think it was going to be possible for Blizzard to pull off an Windfury heavy build but I’m loving it regardless of what the meta is.
I still wish 2h was an option but this is a great move in the right direction personally.

I’ll keep this short and to the point
Elemental shaman has too many buffs to track now it’s exhausting to play

Example:
Icefury stacks, Stormkeeper stacks, Echoes of Great Sundering, Master of the Elements, Power of the Maelstrom, Electrified Shocks etc.
Disclaimer: I’m enhancement and only run keys.
I ran a key with a ~3k ele sham yesterday and he was doing 30k sustained single target only with lightning bolt (he wasn’t running Icefury, didn’t use lava burst and had no totem to manage).
So uhm… unless I’m missing something here, bloated applies to damage, not the rotation?

In theory you CAN build elemental shaman around a “rotation” that requires you to keep track of 5 or so buffs that don’t show up on your personal resource bar (AKA, really hard to keep track of without weakauras).
I only care about earth shield everything else just use something after lava burst Earth shock for example

If you play all of those talents at the same time then I see your concern, however you can simplify the selection without losing much overall DPS, and with a smaller margin for error may even increase your DPS consistently with a simpler approach.
The option to CHOOSE to complicate a spec moreso to increase damage by making a more difficult build more rewarding with good execution is in my opinion excellent design.

Try going heavy into sundering and earthquake and not playing ice fury, or play master of elements without sundering and select all of the fire talents on the right side. Experiment! Have fun with it, but definitely don’t feel like you have to play one singular build. You can be viable and effective simply with proper execution and the kicker is you will have fun playing your way.
I could see the argument that it’s good design if it was like that for all specs, but why would anyone want an over complicated spec when they can just look elsewhere

The point is that you can choose to make it not complicated, that’s what I mean. You don’t HAVE to take master of Elements, echoes of sundering AND icefury. You can take one of them if you want, or two! Whatever your comfortable with. Keep in mind at level 70 you will have 5 more points on your spec tree to move around which will give you more freedom to create builds that you enjoy.
isnt just buff but little “windows” of dmg…that u need to keep track of
u can play an easy rotation? yes, u can even play w/o putting talents at all too , just spam LB …that doesnt make it any better.
Dh spamms one button and deals a lot of DMG. My logic is to follow those classes

I know many players that would advocate for MORE complicated options that offer better rewards with perfect execution. I also play with many guys who want what you want, something simple yet effective (try a BM hunter btw, your welcome!) the best design is to have multiple paths, and I think that’s what they are tying to go for here although it is clearly a work in progress. Unless you are pushing for top world rankings in a form of content, your playstyle preferences can be met regardless of the class/spec you prefer to play. This is good news!

So Resto feels good, but man…both Enhancement and Elemental just feel absolutely horrible. And it’s not just the damage and the survivability ( or mobility in Ele’s case ) but the abilities. Nothing feels synergistic, everything feels clunky. And I absolutely HATE having to fall back on cast-time spells as enhancement when all my abilities are on CD.
Is this something solved by just stacking haste, or did we just get shafted again as a class?

Haste will help, but usually there are not that many gaps if you play with your full damage kit. AoE should be a non-issue, but if you are using Overflowing Maelstrom in single target, it can be more of a hindrance.

To be fair, I usually run with a Lava Lash build in PvE which has a lot more going on between frost shocks, Ice Strikes, Lava Lash, and Storm Strike along with Crash Lightning in AoE. I think Lava Lash is still going to make it’s way into your kit regularly even with a Storm Strike focused build.
Spenders hit hard, but you still want to defer them in PvE in favor of most things off cooldown if you are not about to hit the Maelstrom Weapon stack limit.
On some rare occasions I’ve felt like the weapon imbues might not have been working until I refreshed them and this makes a huge difference in terms of MSW generation with windfury.

For enhancement, there should not ever be a moment that you are hard casting. You must have incredibly poor talent choices, as more often than not I feel like I have TOO much to do and not enough time to hit all of my instant cast attacks. I personally think the uninspired issue is in the talents. My biggest problem at the moment is the baseline shaman tree that I absolutely don’t understand. I don’t understand why the last half of the ‘enhancement’ side is about totem management when we litteraly have no totem management outside tremor on specific occasions. I’m saying this because, currently, lava lash builds outside raiding exclude Windfury totem, and still, we don’t have to ‘manage’ WF totem, we just drop it again when it’s gone/out of reach.

There is absolutely nothing enticing for enhancement in the whole 20 points part of the baseline shaman tree, so we just go the Ancestral guidance route because… well there’s no reason really but we have points to spend so there you go.

The identity crisis of the class is real imo. The talent trees show that whoever is in charge of Shamans is having a hard time trying to figure it out. And here’s a clue: our identity isn’t ToTeMs, get over it already, ele and enhancement barely use any, MOVE ON BLIZZARD.
I would be more ok with totems being our identity if the most useful totems were not locked to restoration (link, tides, cloudburst, etc.)

Feral Lunge fills a role-specific niche for Enhancement similar to Gust of Wind for Resto and Elemental. It is a low-impact, medium-cooldown movement ability that can assist in avoiding mechanics, prevent fall-damage/knockback effects, and increase DPS by maximizing the potential amount of time you have to execute your rotation, and minimizing the amount of time spent moving.
The basics of what would happen:
The nitty-gritty of what would happen:
Not much to discuss here. Every 1 minute you can press Spirit Walk to instantly remove all movement-impairing effects and gain 60% movement speed for 8 seconds.

Things get less explicit here and up for more debate. My personal suggestion is that Graceful Spirit reduces the cooldown of Spirit Walk by 15 seconds, and Spiritwalker’s Aegis grants an additional 2 removals of movement-impairing effects at 4 seconds and 8 seconds after the ability is cast. Since currently it requires 2 capstone talent points to reduce Spirit Walk to 45 seconds, a simple CD reduction attached to Graceful Spirit for Spirit Walk seems fair. Just like before, the second option is more worthwhile in PvP, but there is still a potential to beuseful in PvE content.
Not much to discuss here either. Feral Lunge behaves as it always did.

Go with the Flow would reduce the CD of Feral Lunge by 5 seconds per point, 10 seconds total. While I feel like this is not often worth the cost, very few people are using Go With the Flow currently, anyways. The rationale for Go with the Flow being 2 points is more of a macro talent tree design decision rather than a micro design decision. I will not pretend to have thought about how to restructure the tree to make Go with the Flow worthwhile.

Some of the issues I’ve been thinking about a lot lately are: what’s an Enhancement Shaman’s class identity in PvP? And why don’t many Enhancement shaman exist >2.1k in Arenas/RBGs/Hero of the Horde/Alliance? Outside of Turbocleave comps, where do we really fit in?

The current PvP identity:
Nearly universally, Shaman are considered the kill target in PvP. We deal strong damage and have great self-healing, but have little in the way of defensive abiliites. We don’t have a built-in everything immunity like Iceblock, partial immunity like Turtle Shell or Die by the Sword, or after-death spells like Restitution. We have a ton of utility which disrupts the enemy team’s flow of battle and strong self-heals that can keep us alive in a pinch.

What the identity is lacking in PvP: We were designed as the glass cannons of the Azeroth. We’re the Berserkers of the Vikings, Gladiator’s of the Romans. If we’re nearly universally going to be the kill target, we should also be topping the DPS charts if we’re ignored. We were designed to have incredible pressure, but we’re also designed to be anti-tank mines - why else would Windstrike ignore armor?

The problem: The problem is how we operate within PvE content. The idea of a glass cannon spec is terrible for raids, since healers keep us alive and our mobility allows us to maneuver around tricky AoE. Thus, our damage receives a massive nerf so DPS raid meta isn’t just filled with blue bars. I fully understand it’s necessary for PvE, but it distorts our identity in PvP. In Arenas if our damage is gutted, we’re really only viable in Turbocleave. Since utility is shared amongst all specs, an RBG team can get better healing out of a Resto and better damage out of an Ele if Enhancement damage is gutted. We simply become non-viable since a different spec can fill the position better.
As a side note, many specs have increased generic mobility built into the new talent trees that they can maintain damage and healing during. Shaman do not, as we don’t do much damage as a ghost wolf.

My proposed “easy to implement and balance” solution is a new PvP talent:
Imprint of the Wolf: The Shaman singles out a target, Stormstrike increases its movement speed by 15% when moving towards the target and reducing the targets healing taken by 40%. Their intense focus on this target reduces damage by 10% to additional targets hit by the Shaman.
Doesn’t have to be Storm Strike, but putting it on a cooldown could have the negative side effect of reduced damage when switching targets, particularly if the first wasn’t killed.

It’s an identity driven talent that is essentially a mortal strike effect for Shaman. This would reduce the Shaman’s reliance on Warriors, making it viable in more arena compositions. The current comps for RBGs typically only contain two melee outside of the base-sitters, often a DK for their grips and a warrior for their mortal strike. This ability would help cement the spec identity Enhance in RBGs: paired with Windstrike, we would become legitimate anti-tank mines. With the increased movespeed, we could also stick to the tanks easier, which maintains the status quo of ‘kill the Shaman’ and makes us a threat at all levels of PvP.

It changes nothing for PvE, and requires no additional talent balancing outside of balancing the mortal strike/move speed/collateral damage effect, and allows the nerfs to our baseline damage to have less of an effect in PvP content.
I ran a few BGs (no solo shuffle) last night on Beta with the Devs. I was running Doomwinds, elemental blast, elemental spirits, and all the Ascendance talents.

It really wasn’t too bad. The highest EB crit I had was a 100k EB with the 10 stack MW talent. I ran a couple games without the 10 stack MW crit talent and got lucky with two 50K EBs back to back. The rest of our damage is middle of the pack. I think the highest dam I did overall was around 8 or 9 million total, but I was playing objectives rather than zug zug the entire game at all the team fights.
The hardest crit I took was a 250K fire breath from an Evoker. Almost a complete 1 Shot lol. They might wanna look at that ability before this goes live.

The increased health pools definitely felt weird. There were times when I didn’t think I was doing much to lower my targets health bar, but there were several times when it seemed like they weren’t doing much to mine either. There were a few exceptions. With proper ramp up and CDs, a Ret can kill in a single stun. DHs were the only class - that I saw at least - that seem to constantly be applying real pressure… to everyone all at once without taking ANY damage themselves.
While I was doing mid range total dps of around 8 to 9 mill, classes like DH, feral druid, Warlock and Evoker were pumping around 16-18 mill total.
I think, as of right now, we’re a mid B Tier class… at least in terms of this BG beta test. But there were quite a few A and S Tier classes. Just what I saw personally. Was anyone else there?
Thanks for the feedback on this.

I think the problem blizz has is they don’t have a clue what Enh Shaman should be. We’re built to be glass cannons, high damage, high self heals, very little in the way of damage reduction. Basically the Berserkers of the Vikings, Gladiator’s of the Romans.

The problem is: the idea of a Glass Cannon is terrible for raiding. The ‘glass’ part is compensated by healers and the mobility to avoid AoE, and the cannon part would just force most raids to play Enh meta strictly for the high damage output.

The second problem is that the devs don’t care enough about Enh PvP to actually allow us to play like we’re supposed to be played. There are not and have never been more than a few Enh Heroes of the Horde. There are extremely few Enh over 2.1k, relative to other classes. There are particularly few outside of Turbocleave, essentially the only arena comp we consistently perform well in.

While messing around with talents on live last night, I noticed that NS consumes both its own buff and a stack of up to 5 of maelstrom weapon when you use a spell/ability that is affected by both. Even if you’re not at a total of 5 maelstrom weapon, it will do the same for 1-4 stacks as well.
Is this an issue the devs are aware of?
This isn’t an issue and is working as intended.
Maelstrom Weapons doesn’t just reduce cast time, but also increases the spell power of said cast.
There is no reason to think using NS wouldn’t consume these, as they still boost the spell’s output and MW stacks work on any casted spell, regardless if it is instant or not.
Understood, but it’s just kind of frustrating that the NS gets wasted in these situations.

Let’s say I use NS followed immediately by a 5 stack MW empowered Elemental Blast. The EB is instant and benefits from the spell power increase from MW, but it also consumed the NS with no benefit? If this is solely based on MW’s design, then you should at least keep the NS buff to instant cast the next nature spell you cast. It shouldn’t just disappear because MW is working as intended.

Back when Lava Burst was first introduced to the game, it was one of those awesome heavy-hitting spells that you’d always want to keep off cooldown. It always crit, and it crit hard because Elemental Shamans just crit harder.
Fast forward today and that same spell is just weak sauce. When your filler (lightning bolt) spell is doing more damage per cast time then something’s wrong.
Simply put: Lava Burst needs a buff. I’m not sure why its become so weak over the years, but some people have pointed out that maybe its because it’s being balanced around always critting.
A simple solution to balancing always-critting spells is to do just do what Blizz already did with Destro Warlock Chaos Bolt: increase its damage by your crit chance.

Another thing I’ve noticed is that the Fire (right) side of the Elemental Shaman tree just doesn’t have too many things that actually buffs the damage of Lava Burst. You have Flux Melting which is in the middle. Then you have improved Flametongue Weapon, which is disgustingly weak, seriously 5% extra fire damage for a talent node that far down the tree? That’s like 25% total extra damage from talents.
Meanwhile lightning builds have a plethora of things that increase their damage via Stormcaller, Electrified Shocks, Master of the Elements, Lightning Rod, Surge of Power, and Echo Chamber.
I just think they seriously need to buff the Fire side of Elemental Shaman, and they should start with Lava Burst. What do y’all think?

I do not think this nerf for enhancement is fair. When is ok to just say “we are nerfing a spec 25%” with no explanation or answers? I get that parts of enhancement spec were over performing but an explanation would be very helpful. With other class nerfs blizzard often provides an explanation of why they are nerfing a class, hell with Elemental they picked and chose what ability to buff. But enhancement gets just 25% nerf to EVERYTHING. That is not an insignificant change and feels really bad and honestly makes me want to just go back to warrior main when I was really excited to play enhancement come DF. If you just want to nerf the entire spec 25%, ok, fine. But could you please give us some details why? Did flame shock need 25%? Did frost shock need 25%? how about chain lightning? Thanks for any info.

I really wanted to play enhance but if this nerf makes it a bottom tier spec im going to play something else, and I’m not even a hug min maxer. I just want an actually chance at top 3 dps in mythic prog, thank you for your time.
I posted this on the beta forums.
Dear Blizzard,

While I know you may not even read this I feel better writing this knowing there might be a chance you do. Is it possible like how you’ve did with Discipline Priest get a in-depth post on the recent Nerfs towards Enhancement spec.

While I do agree certain nerfs where inevitable, certain skills such as Elemental Blast was hitting ridiculously high, I thought certain skills would be nerfed and tuned down to be more inline with other dps classes, but never did I imagine such a across the board nerf would be warranted.

Playing Enhancement over the last few months since I’ve had access to now the beta servers actually rejuvenated my love and passion for the spec, “Finally Enhance was back to being truely fun again”, it brought back so much nostalgia I had from MoP expansion, I was falling back in love with my favourite old spec.

I really do hope you could provide some insight and clarity on the decision made, would further tuning happen?, are you happy currently where Enhance is post nerf?. My biggest fear and worry is now with this nerf you really created further issues especially with the talent system.

Enhancement has lost its build diversity through the talent tree, it’s gutted the build diversity immensely and now we have to try and scrounge the most optimal build regardless if we enjoy it or not to optimise our dps as efficiently as possible to stay competitive.

I say this because while on beta, I played a build I truely fell in love with, through days of tweaking and different iterations I turned up with a fun, decent build focused on Stormstrike, while yes it may not be optimal but it did decent enough dps inline with most other dps averaging out between 35-50k dps overall, honestly it was more so dependant on how many or when deeply rooted elements procd. I actually tried to prepare for the Elemental Blast nerf so I choose not to run it.

Now my fun build, that was performing decently well, outside of certain other dps specs killing the dps metres, I’m doing absolutely rubbish dps. Certain Tanks are pretty much on par with my dps and I’m now left with a horrible non viable build. It’s truely upsetting and kills the motivation to play Enhancement.
While it’s still truely plays the same, and is fun, it definitely no where able to perform in high keys or raiding .

I just hope you could reconsider certain nerfs to skills and abilities that weren’t over performing, and just give a little insight and clarification on the changes, a little communication will definitely go a long way.
Is this a prepatch nerf? Or are we diving into dragonflight totally gimped? I’ve never seen anything like this. What the hell man. This is crazy.

It feels like lay devs or they just don’t give a **** about the community they are effecting. Like ok, you think a 25% nerf on EVERYTHING is warranted, can we at least get one sentence why? not everyone is on the beta or a high end pvper.
Sometimes I feel like some devs just care more about the community than others
Beta, we are in shambles, basically you need to pick now most viable talents to be competitive at the low end of the dps metres :(. Sort of killed build diversity, it’s back to meta or nothing.
The Nerf crushed me, don’t get me wrong Enhance is still fun to play, but doing abysmal dps is very disheartening.

I’m really hoping…more like praying things get tuned and balanced, Elemental Blast was hitting like a truck, I agree that should of been nerfed, I didn’t even run it cause I anticipated it be nerfed hard, but never in a million years I could have seen such a insane nerf hitting the spec as a whole.
I couldn’t tell you if it was really warranted at all, but I’m still finishing mythic + right now in mid 20ks.
